abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Belize City
            Infrastructure Project for Belize were as follows: the
            overall project outcomes were marginally satisfactory, Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a) a
            clearly-defined and articulated sectoral and institutional
            policy framework is necessary to provide direction and
            rationale for project works, sharpen project goals, set
            priorities, minimize conflicts and avoid ad-hoc and costly
            non-sustainable initiatives; b) incorporating the active
            participation of all stakeholders at the earliest stage of a
            proposed project and continuation of this practice during
            all subsequent phases is a necessary condition for viable
            success and to build ownership. Pressure to rush to achieve
            physical results should be tempered by appropriate advances
            in the complementary legal, institutional financial and
            related areas which are necessary to assure sustainability
            of such works; c) more realism is needed about what can be
            achieved in terms of institutional development and how. The
            institutional, administrative financial, legal and related
            framework should be very clearly-defined understood and
            agreed-upon by all parties and these should include clear
            procedures not only for the conceptual phase but also for
            making them operational; and d) new investments should not
            be the answer to chronic deferred operation and maintenance
            deficiencies. Without full appreciation of, and commitment
            to the need for adequate operation and maintenance
            provisions such projects will not be sustainable.

5079532.trustfund:
TF035447-LAC REGION - WASTE WATER
            MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (ST. VINCENT,,TF033419-BELIZE - PUBLIC EXPENDITURE REVIEW
5079532.majtheme: Human development,Environment and natural resource management,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project seeks to:  (a) improve
            health and safety of Belize City dwellers; (b) preserve the
            rich ecology of the city and its environs, one of the most
            important assets of the country; (c) promote economic
            development of the city, in particular provide a boost to
            tourism, the fastest growing industry in the country; and
            (d) strengthen city capacity for infrastructure maintenance
            and delivery of urban services.  The project provides for:
            (a) rehabilitation of street network and traffic management;
            (b) improvement of the drainage system including canals and
            creeks; (c) coastal protection and berth facilities; and (d)
            strengthening the city's capacity to maintain its
            infrastructure and improve the delivery of urban services.
